title: the tory party is over
story: What the Tories think of Boris Johnson is irrelevant. The PM will soon be out on his earThe Conservative Party is like an abused we with no other home to go to, and in two minds about whether this is survivable, says Fleet Street Fox. It isnt Image: Getty ImagesopinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsWell. The Prime Minister is under direct criminal investigation. The evidence of his alleged crimes are being kept hidden from him for fear of interference.And with war brewing on Europeaposs eastern flank, the PM told the enemy he didnapost have time to ring, because he had too much arse-covering to do.The Conservative Party is like an abused we with no other home to go to, and in two minds, not about whether this is acceptable, but whether itaposs survivable. And like every victim, it has yet to realisethataposs the question, then itaposs time to go.  Yesterday, a report he resisted ordering was not published. Instead, there was an aposupdateapos on the alleged criminality of his office, his staff, and his personal residence, and the PM greeted it in the same way he has every Mirror front page, ITV broadcast, and BBC breaking news update since late November: a burst of surprise and contrition with a half-le of . seconds, decaying into toxic belligerence that will linger in the bone for a thousand years. Events for which there was not enough evidence to merit an investigation by the politan Police had, in the space of a month, uncovered  witnesses,  photographs, and  pieces of paper.Despite the insufficient evidence,  out of  parties, on  dates, have met the evidential threshold for an investigation, on the grounds that those involved knew they were against the rules, there was no reasonable justication for them, and not looking into it would end Cressida Dickaposs career quicker than sending the riot squad into a candlelit vigil.One of them is an alleged gathering in the Downing Street flat on November , , which Mrs Johnsonaposs personal spokeswoman has repeatedly insisted is total nonsense, but about which there seems to be enough evidence to merit weeks of attention by an entire squad of coppers.  While the -page report has been subbed down to just , it contains all the facts needed to decide the PMaposs future. Extensive, substantive, factual information is now available, wrote Sue Gray. There were failures of leadership and judgement. There was excessive consumption of alcohol. There was no way for those working in government to stop it breaking the law. There was a serious failure to observe, not just the standards expected of those working at the heart of government, but also of the standards expected of the entire British population at the time.The killer line is in paragraph . The excuse of long hours worked in the pandemic, in a building that could not be entirely Covid-secure, was destroyed. Those challenges... also applied to key and frontline workers across the country who were working under equally,not more, demanding conditions, often at risk to their own health... criminal sanctions were applied to many... the hardship under which citizens across the country worked, lived and sadly even died while observing the Governmentaposs regulations and guidance are known only too well. Every citizen has been impacted by the pandemic. One of them is Leshie Chandrapala. Her dad drove a bus. He died of Covid, and Leshie was not allowed to be with him as he lay in a coma in ICU. She believes he died because he didnapost get PPE at work, but the government hasnapost even written a letter of condolence to her family. A fortnight after he died, and while she grieved, they threw the BYO booze Downing Street garden party. The PMaposs response to the report was to say sorry for the way itaposs been handled, not sorry for doing it. And he has a solution. I know what the issue is, he declared. I get it, and I will fix it! He says he is taking personal charge, and setting up the Office of the Prime Minister. So who was in charge of his office for the past three years  Where is the drunken boozehound who careered around Downing Street Friday night drinkathons, encouraging staffers to let off steam with a long chug on the vodka bottle  Who allowed the culture of recklessness and lawlessness, at the heart of a government that was criminalising the same sins in others  Which leader has led his party to a disgrace worse than Windrush or Grenfell or Orgreave Bring me his head! bellows Boris from the Despatch Box. I will slay this beast, the same way that I would have slain Jimmy Savile,only I didnapost think that investigating historical sex abuse was money spaffed up the wall!Other things he has taken personal control of include Brexit, social care, test and trace, the energy crisis, the ministerial code of conduct, the saving of Owen Paterson, and funding for his gold wallpaper. The fact he took personal control of the vaccines may have something to do with the fact that  million people donapost want them. How many times has he taken charge, only for things to spin out of control  How many times has he shaken up the civil service, only to be rattled himself  Read more The nation is now watching the Conservative Party the same way as the rest of the street watches a victim get out of the police car, andto their abuser. They drag with them a whole country into this deranged, gnarled, unhappy misgovernment, back to the man who wonapost promise to publish the full truth in the House of Commons, where he might be held in contempthe failed to, but will promise it in the bar, to the MPs he has lied to for years, and who have been brainwashed into thinking such a promise is a concession rather than a repetition.Meanwhile the PM only appears in public when the public can be kept away from him. Abba tribute bands are raising their prices for satin satire. Andyou want a three-word slogan to describe where we are, it is simply: another fine mess. The PM or his we may get a fixed penalty notice pictures may or may not emerge. He may be out on his ear, or he may convince enough MPs to give him one more go. Itaposs irrelevant, because the fallout of this radioactive scandal will last to the ballot box and beyond it reaches into homes and hearts, to the guts and spines of millions to whom the words aposToryapos and aposPartyapos are now as repugnant as the fact that people like Leshie had their pain doubled and then dismissed by a man whose charm has long since been spent. The Tories got drunk on power, picked a man who can be fooled by a cake, and then dithered about whether to let him keep hurting the rest of us. They cannot see what the rest of us can: their party is over. title: bamboo plant causes devastating 100000
story: Bamboo plant causes devastating £, damage to horried neighbours homeBamboo planted at a Hampshire home somehow grew under the neighbours property and broke through its concrete floor - causing a huge £, worth of damageThe only way to solve the problem was to dig up the ground floor of the Hampshire house Image: Environet UKByLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsHomeowners have been issued an urgent warning after a home faced £, worth of damage caused by a running bamboo plant.Bamboo was planted at the property to form some of the border hedge, but allegedly it was left unmonitored and grew as a result.The plantaposs roots grew underneath the next door home and broke through its concrete floor. It then continued to grow through the propertyaposs cavity walls and eventually it would have forced the walls apartit hadnapost been tackled. The only way to solve the problem was to dig up the ground floor of the Hampshire house and remove hundreds of metres of bamboo rhizomes. The home insurance claim for the damage was apparently more than £,, reports the Express.Japanese Knotweed is famously a nightmare, but experts have said bamboo can be just as baditaposs left to grow unmonitored. The roots of bamboo can travel up to a whopping  metres and they can break through all sorts of surfaces, from bricks and drains to cavity walls and patios.  aposRunningapos ieties of bamboo like the one found at the Hampshire property are particularly prolic as they send lateral shoots out underneath the ground which can sometimes pop up on neighboursapos plots. Founder and MD of Environet UK, Nic Seal, told the Sun: Through no fault of their own, the homeowners have suffered signicant financial cost, stress and inconvenience, being required to vacate their home for several months. The truth is, most bamboos are invasiveplanted directly into the ground and left to their own devices. He added that the Hampshire case was the worst case of bamboo encroachment heaposd ever seen in this country. Experts advise itaposs best to choose a clumping iety of bamboo rather than a running iety to avoid spreading problems like these. Those buying bamboo should also plant it in a pot instead of in the ground and make sure to trim it frequently. title: bbc filmmaker stalked student who
story: BBC filmmaker stalked student who rejected him and left her too scared to leave homeRiagain Grainger, , stalked fellow student Georgia Smith, , threatened to mutilate and kill her, often standing outside her home after she rejected his advancesRiagain Grainger,  Image: PAByAlec WhitakerKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Feb |comments An award winning BBC and Netflix filmmaker who stalked and threatened to kill a student who rejected his advances, has been jailed for two and a half years.Riagain Grainger had been nominated for awards at Cannes Film Festival, and won awards in Paris, and New York along with earning the admiration of Oscar winning actor Sir Ben Kingsley.The -year-old stalked Georgia Smith and relentlessly bullied her online, setting up up to  Instagram accounts as he encouraged her to kill herself and promised to kill and mutilate her body.Then, he went on to post pictures of her on multiple pornographic websites after editing them to look like pornographic images and invited her to take her own le, or be killed by him. Grainger attended Manchester politan University along with Miss Smith, , and loitered outside her student home and posted pictures of it on social media with captions reading: aposaposI am watching every move you make.” Another disturbing message read: aposaposWhat happens when a brick smashes through your window - you scream. “I have been watching every step you have made within the last week I know where you have been Iaposve followed you places you haven’t even noticed.”  In a statement Miss Smith, from Middlesbrough, told police: aposaposI will not feel safe again until I know he can no longer hurt me. “What happened became so regular I would barely have time to breath before there was another message. aposaposWhen I heard the phone ring, I would have a panic attack. It was the fear of what these messages said. “I have always struggled with my appearance but I was confident enough not to care - however these messages have torn my confidence away. They have made me think about my weight, facial features and even the colour of my hair. aposaposIt made me feel smaller and smaller every single day. I did not leave my bedroom for weeks on end. I could not do anything as I felt ashe was watching and following me. “At university he would stare at me from across the room and spent my entire third year living at home panicking he was outside my front door. aposaposI have constant nightmares about him which have not stopped that he is torturing me. My anxiety has never been so high and I cannot be the person I should be because of him. “He took away my choice to learn how to live and be independent and I find it hard to trust anyone as I have an innate fear it will happen to me again.aposapos Grainger began stalking Ms Smith between September and October  and was further ordered to pay Miss Smith £, compensation. Further inquiries revealed he had used social media to harass two other young women. In some messages, Grainger told Ms Smith: “Have you ever thought about killing yourself. Kill yourself – everyone wants that. Go jump off a bridge. I cannot wait to plunge this kne into your stomach and see you in pain. No one thinks you’re pretty.aposapos Sentencing Judge Timothy Smith told Grainger: aposaposYou subjected Ms Smith to a protracted, persistent stalking campaign by attending outside her home address and bombarding her with the most vile, abusive and threatening messages that were calculated and intended to cause her real harm, distress and upset. “It was a torrent of the most cruel, mean, abusive, abhorrent, vile, vindictive, and hate filled invective. aposaposEvery time she blocked an Instagram account, within minutes, there would be a new message. She would wake up and have several dferent accounts messaging her with multiple messages. She could scarcely breathe before there would be another. aposaposEventually Ms Smith removed herself from Instagram entirely to prevent more messaging however you simply moved to Facebook with profile pictures included those of Ms Smith edited to look like pornographic images – as well as one picture of a person who had blood pouring down her face.aposaposThey are some of the nastiest and most repellent messages I have seen. They were crafted and designed to abuse, undermine, demean, harm, hurt and generate fear - and they clearly did so.” The court was told how the pair met in March , at a nightclub in Manchester. They swapped numbers and social media accounts and became friends, but issues began to arise when Ms Smith went home for the summer and Grainger began messaging her saying he was lonely. Mr Ben Berkson, prosecuting, said: aposaposShe went on a holiday with other university mates and this angered Mr Grainger who felt affronted that her other friends were prioritised over him. Ms Smith stopped contact with him and deleted him off Instagram and Snapchat. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  aposaposBut she was then subjected to frequent and insulting messages on Facebook and Instagram from unknown accounts. “She naturally blocked those accounts however more and more messages were being sent to her and Ms Smith discovered her Instagram photographs were being used on multiple porn websites. aposaposThere was also a threat to kill issued to Ms Smith from an account describing how they would like to plunge a kne into her stomach and slitting her throat. “Ms Smith also received images taken outside her accommodation at university. In total,  Instagram accounts had been used to send messages harassing Ms Smith who eventually deleted her own Instagram account to stop the abuse. aposaposBut her friends and family then began receiving friend requests from Instagram and Facebook profiles invented by the defendant but in Georgia Smith’s name. The defendant played on her insecurities.  aposaposThere is a certain vulnerability about a young girl who has fled the nest for the first time for university. She was left in the knowledge that edited pictures of her are now on the internet on porn sites, which is a particularly spiteful aspect of this offending. aposaposHer housemates had to pace the streets in order to try and identy the inidual who was terrorising their friend. On one occasion they apprehended Mr Grainger who was stalking their house – telling him to leave the area on multiple occasions.aposapos Grainger was arrested in October  after being spotted lurking outside Ms Smithaposs house by her boyfriend. Police found incriminating pictures of the property on his pen drives and mobile phone and discovered internet searches for images of aposaposbloody bodies.aposapos He later ly claimed an ex-girlfriend sent malicious messages to Ms Smith. The court heard he had a caution for harassment for  and was subject to a two year probation order at Belfast for harassing a third woman. In mitigation defence counsel Michael Goldwater: aposaposFrom living in a small farming community, he moved to Manchester for his education which was a culture shock coming from his background. “He had undiagnosed mental health issues at that stage and was drawn to the victim because she struggles from similar dficulties which he did. aposaposBecause of his mental health, he did not take rejection well and the ending of the relationship caused him to break down.” Riagain Grainger, , was sentenced at Manchester Crown Court after he admitted stalking involving fear of violence, serious alarm and distress, a spokesman for Greater Manchester Police said. Grainger was also subject to an indefinite stalking prevention order.After the case Det Con Thomas Small, of Greater Manchester Police said: aposaposStalking can have a devastating effect on a victim and their loved ones. Everyone has the right to live their le without fear and harassment, and Grainger made that impossible for this young woman.aposaposRead MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CrimeStalking" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: covid cases now almost 200000
story: Covid cases now almost at , a day with infections increasing, new data suggestsThe ZOE study data estimates that the current R value is at . for England, Scotland and Wales. It also shows that in England  in  have Covid, with  in  in Wales and  in  in ScotlandProfessor Tim Spector leads the ZOE study Image: Ken McKay ITV REX ShutterstockByKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsCovid cases across the UK have increased by  per cent since last week and are at almost ,, data from the ZOE study has revealed.The figures, which are based on both PCR and LFT test data, also estimates that the current R value is at . for England, Scotland and Wales. There are currently , new daily symptomatic coronavirus cases in the UK on average, based on test data from up to three days ago, which is an increase of  per cent from , reported last week. Of those, those who were vaccinated with at least two doses made up , of the new daily symptomatic cases in the UK, up from , new daily cases last week.The study also shows that in England  in  have covid, with  in  in Wales and  in  in Scotland.  It also reveals that cases are now rising in all age groups, but the rise is much smaller in the + age groups, particularly in the older, more vulnerable + group, the increase is very small. According to the data, ZOE estimates that  per cent of people experiencing new “cold-like“ symptoms are likely to have symptomatic Covid.Professor Tim Spector, lead scientist on the ZOE COVID Study app, said: “While the bad news is we are again approaching , new cases a day, it’s encouraging that recorded hospitalisations, ICU cases and deaths are still coming down as Omicron is less severe in a vaccinated population.With a lag of several weeks between infections and hospitalisations, we’ll continue to monitor this rate closely in the coming weeks. We saw a similar rebound and second peak during the Delta wave as people relaxed more and children went back to school. It seems many are, again, preempting the end of the Covid- pandemic.It’s much too early for this.High case rates will likely be with us until late spring before the warmer weather and the summer holidays help reduce infections again.He addd: Over the past few weeks, the UK governmentaposs confirmed cases data has begun to move further away from ZOE’s findings. There are a number of reasons for this. The biggest factor is the change in testing behaviour that has happened this year. ZOE Contributors are now logging more positive LFTs in the app, and fewer PCRs. LFTs no longer have to be confirmed by a PCR so are often not being logged with the government, so confirmed case data is missing thousands of LFT results, leading to massive under-reporting. This subtle but important change in behaviour, highlights the importance of having multiple methods to track COVID in the population and shows the power of the citizen scientists that log with ZOE every day. The way ZOE collects and analyses the data means our data is always ahead of the other national surveys that are just beginning to show rises.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON AppsEducationCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news devastated-parents-pupils-tears-school-"Derek Barlow on the devastating Ash Green school fireByAndrew RobinsonConnor Teale:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb  Much of a primary school has been reduced to ash after a huge fire burned it to the ground.Parents and pupils have been left devastated and in tears following the devastating blaze at Ash Green Primary school in Halax, West Yorkshire on Tuesday night.Fty firefighters battled to control the inferno, but they were unable to save the schoolaposs roof, Yorkshire Live reported. A -year-old man, who was found at the scene by officers, remains in custody after being arrested on suspicion of arson. The man was also taken to hospital for treatment on Tuesday. Gazing upon the destruction on Wednesday, parents whose children currently attend the school and former pupils spoke of how the fire has devastated a whole community. Ex-pupil Valerija Balinskaite, , said she broke down after hearing the news.  I was in tears, she said. It was awful. I live just a five minutesapos walk from the school. I saw a video of the fire and it just broke me. I have so many happy memories from the school. Grace Berry, whose seven-year-old daughter attends the school, said: It is just devastating for the community. It is devastating for the kids and teachers to wake up to these circumstances. But it is a strong community and I am sure it will pull together and pull through - these things tend to bring people together. Derek Barlow said the school is widely considered as iconic in the local area, and many of the people living nearby graced its hallways when they were younger. My we went there and I have had two children who have been to this school, he said. It was a bit gut-wrenching watching it last night. My we was sending me photos of it . She was very upset about it and the community is very upset about it, actually. The community is absolutely devastated about it - this school is iconic.  Headteacher Mr Mungo Sheppard said that emergency services had managed to save quite a bit of the building. I have no idea how quickly we can get back in, he continued. We have completely lost four classrooms for our year , ,  and  children. The direct fire damage has spread no further than that, so we have been able to save quite a lot of our school. It is devastating for these children. They are in tears because they canapost come to school today and they do not know what they are going to come back to. Mr Sheppard added that some children may have to be educated at other sites while repair work takes place at the school. Leader of Calderdale Council, Cllr Tim Swt, said: It was heartbreaking to hear the news yesterday evening about the fire at Ash Green Community Primary School.  My thoughts are with all the staff, parents and of course the pupils who usually attend this school. We know how much disruption our schools have faced throughout the Covid pandemic, so itaposs particularly upsetting that Ash Green and the local community is now facing a further period of upheaval. The school is working hard to make sure children are well supported and plans are being put in place to minimise disruption for pupils as much as possible. We are working closely with the school to support this and to assist with the recovery process going forward. Ten fire engines and one aerial ladder  were used to subdue the flames.A spokesperson for West Yorkshire Police said: Enquiries are continuing today into the fire at Ash Green Primary School in Mixenden.A -year-old man who was arrested on suspicion of arson is currently in custody. Anyone with information about the fire should call Calderdale District CID on , quoting log number  of February . Information can also be given anonymously to the independent charity Crimestoppers on  Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON West Yorkshire PoliceSchoolsArson" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news drivers-parking-pavements-face-being-"Martin Lewis explains council and private company parking finesByRachel PughFelix ReevesKieren Williams:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments Every driver in England risks being slapped with a £ fine for bad parking under a new law that could come into power soon.Under new plans drawn up, fixed penalty notices could be given out to those who park on the street, eventhere’s no double yellow lines.If the laws pass through parliament, and drivers park up on a pavement, blocking a narrow road or the pathway itself, they could risk the £ fine. This comes as a quarter of motorists said they were unsure of the rules around parking on pavements,Manchester Evening News reported .New laws around parking on pavements are one of many coming into power this year. And as well as facing fines, drivers caught breaking the new laws could be hit with points on their license too.  Some of these changes are still under consultation in England and Wales, but it is believed that local councils will have more power when it comes to fining reckless parkers. However, parking on pavements is already illegal in London and some other parts of the UK. Scotland’s rulings are expected to come into force in . Whilst some drivers may wrongly think parking on the pavement is fine, and barely an offence, the paths are there for the safety of pedestrians. If blocked, pedestrians might be forced to walk around in the road, which is jeopardises their safety.  Alex Kindred, car insurance expert at Confused, told the MEN: “What may seem a small inconvenience to some, might be a huge hindrance to others. “But it’s important to remember that pavements are there for the use and safety of pedestrians only, and therefore should be respected by all other road users. “However, without a clearer understanding of the law around pavement parking, it’ll be hard to implement fines to drivers who break the rules. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  “The current laws around pavement parking can be quite confusing, which is why it’s dficult at times to prosecute drivers. “With consultations ongoing for England and Wales, with Scotland already pioneering the way to make a big change, drivers should be wary that changes could come into force sooner rather than later. “Councils will be given a bigger responsibility and penalty charges could be issued. “The laws around parking on pavements is just one of many new driving laws coming into effect this year, with road user safety at the forefront of each.”  More than  percent of drivers said they have had to park on a pavement in the past, with more than two in five saying they felt danger in doing so. The issue can be particularly dangerous for children and those with disabilities. A number of changes were made in the Highway Code recently which aims to protect all road users from unnecessary danger.  One of the rules involved pavements and the potential danger cyclists and pedestrians face when travelling down them. Rule  of the Highway Code states: “When using an electric vehicle charge point, you should park close to the charge point and avoid creating a trip hazard for pedestrians from trailing cables. “Display a warning signyou can. After using the charge point, you shouldcharging cables and connectors neatly to minimise the danger to pedestrians and avoid creating an obstacle for other road users.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Highways England" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: golden retriever puppy who wobbles
story: Golden retriever puppy who wobbles when she walks needs surgery to stop painAdorable Roxy went from being a crazy little puppy running around everywhere to a six-month-old dog in a lot of pain, after being diagnosed with hip dysplasiaGoldie puppy that wobbles when she walks needs surgery to take away her pain Image: Rebecca NorthByNia DaltonSpecialist Writer:,  Feb |commentsAn adorable golden retriever puppy needs le-changing surgery to stop her wobbling when she walks, after being diagnosed with hip dysplasia. Six-month-old Roxy went from being a crazy little puppy running around everywhere to a dog with pain in her big brown eyes. Just two weeks ago, the puppyaposs back legs suddenly went wobbly and she couldnapost get up off the sofa. She now needs to raise £, before she can have a double hip replacement, as the surgery exceeds her pet insurance cover. Without surgery, Roxy will remain in extreme pain and discomfort, but with new hips, she can live a fulfilled and happy le like any other dog.  Owner Rebecca North, based in Guildford, Surrey, bought eight-week-old Roxy from a good breeder last September. Rebecca’s husband, Elvis, and their two children, Kayleigh, , and Kieran, , “absolutely fell in love” with Roxy, as did her new sibling, two-year-old golden retriever, Kaleb. Rebecca describes Roxy as “the most adorable, loving dog”. Roxy has a “mischievous” side and loves nothing more than playing with the children - and occasionally eating wallpaper. “She will happily lay on the floor with her toys around her,” Rebecca said. On January , Rebecca and Kayleigh took Roxy for her first off-lead run around the local common. “She was absolutely fine, running around like a crazy little puppy”, Rebecca said. “Then later that day, when I was at work, Kayleigh sent me a video of Roxy struggling to get up off the sofa. “It was like her back legs couldn’t work.” Rebecca rushed home and worryingly contacted her local vet, who prescribed pain killer injections. “At first, the vet thought it was a pulled muscle, but after several visits she was diagnosed with hip dysplasia,” Rebecca said. Now, Roxy is “really wobbly on her back legs” and struggles to play. “When she walks, you can see the pain in her little face,” Rebecca said. “Her big brown eyes look really sad at the moment. It breaks my heart.” Roxy has been referred to an orthopaedic specialist to have a “gold standard” double hip replacement, which would cost £, per hip. Her pet insurance only covers £, of the £, total - meaning the family need to find £, to give Roxy a second chance at le. “If she doesn’t have the surgery, it will lead to osteoarthritis and she will be in extreme pain and discomfort,” Rebecca explained. “It would limit her ability to be a puppy and play. “If she has the operation, she will live a fulfilled and happy le like any other dog.”  There is a possibility that young Roxy may be a candidate for a Triple Pelvic Osteotomy , which costs less money - but is still more than the pet insurance will cover. “Very few dogs are elected for TPO,” Rebecca said.Ten days ago, daughter Kayleigh decided to set up aGoFundMe pagefor family and friends to donate towards Roxyaposs surgery.So far, they have raised £ towards their goal. “If Roxy is elected for TPO, she will have surgery in the next two weeks,” Rebecca said. “If she needs to have a full hip replacement, she will have the operation as soon as we’ve raised enough funds.” If you’d like to help fix Roxy’s wobbly back legs, you can donate to herGoFundMe page. title: huge 60000 year old woolly
story: Huge ,-year-old woolly mammoth found under new-build town in incredible discoveryThe mammoth could be up to , years old and was one of a number of historic animals discovered at the site including a wolf, rhinoceros, hyena, and moreThe mammoth tusk recovered from the site Image: AC Archaeology   Sherford Consor SWNSByKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Feb |comments The skeletal remains of woolly mammoth has been discovered in Devon, in an incredible find.The remains of the , year old species were uncovered in the new-build town of Sherford, near Plymouth.However, the woolly mammoth was not the only discovery, as several other well-preserved species were found as well including a rhinoceros, wolf, hyena, horse, reindeer, mountain hare and red fox, DevonLive reported.Experts believe that they could have been from around the last Ice Age, which spanned from ,-, years ago. The archaeological team conducted detailed scientic sampling to try and find out as much about the remains as possible. It was led by a team that includes Orion Heritage, Exeter-based AC Archaeology and a number of academic experts supported by the South West Science Advisor from Historic England.  Rob Bourn, Managing Director of Orion Heritage and lead archaeologist on the project for the Sherford Consortium, said: “This is a major discovery of national signicance – a once in a letime experience for those involved. Construction happening at Sherford is the sole reason these findings have been discovered and it is remarkable that they have laid undisturbed until now. To find such an array of artefacts untouched for so long is a rare and special occurrence. Equally rare is the presence of complete or semi-complete inidual animals.  We look forward to reaching the stage where the discoveries can be shared and displayed, so that everyone can find out more about our distant past.” The project has involved a close partnership with Devon County Council’s Historic Environment Team – as archaeological advisors to South Hams District Council – and the programme of investigations has been informed by specialist advice and expertise from the local archaeological and geological community. The animal bones and environmental samples have been carefully recorded and removed from the ground and are now undergoing academic analysis and conservation. It is expected that the full archive of remains willto Devon, into the care of The Box – Plymouth’s new museum – just a few miles from where they were uncovered.  Victoria Pomery, CEO at The Box, said: “What an amazing discovery this is. We already have some fascinating items in the collections at The Box from this era, some of which provided the inspiration for the hugely popular woolly mammoth and cave lion skeleton we have on display in our natural history gallery. Once all the analysis work is completed it will be a huge honour to care for and display these newly discovered finds, and to play an ongoing part in the public’s understanding of Plymouth and the animals that were here during the Ice Age.”  Duncan Wilson, Chief Executive of Historic England, said: “This discovery is exceptional. To have found partial remains of such a range of species here in Devon gives us a brilliant insight into the animals which roamed around Ice Age Britain thousands of years ago, as well as a better understanding of the environment and climate at the time. We are delighted that this important part of our history will be preserved for future generations.”  The Sherford Consortium will preserve the area where the remains have been found. The underground space will be conserved, and no construction will take place on top of it. However, the entrance will be closed to both protect the historic site and ensure public welfare. It is not, nor will be, possible for the public to safely access the area in which the discoveries have been made. Experts are not % sure as to how all the animals got there, but have a number of theories.  Whether all of the creatures uncovered at Sherford coexisted in a similar time period, or existed at dferent points over a much longer time span is uncertain. One theory is that some of the creatures fell into a pit and were unable to escape, and carnivorous scavengers followed and met a similar fate – or the animals died where and the bones washed into the area over a period of time. Rob Bourn adds, “The South West would have been very dferent back then it was an area where mammoths and other creatures thrived, roaming great distances across a landscape that looked very dferent to today. With glaciers not far away in South Wales, and a volatile climate prone to huge floods, what we have found at Sherford may well have died somewhere nearby and were washed up here to create this unique collection of historic remains.”  The signicance of the recovered remains lies in their likely age and potential to provide clues about le in Britain in the last Ice Age, and the array of bones from dferent animals has especially intrigued experts. The detailed samples taken from the site have so far uncovered: Partial remains of a woolly mammoth, including a tusk, molar tooth and other bones Partial remains of a woolly rhinoceros, including an incomplete skull and lower jaw A virtually complete wolf skeleton Partial remains of hyena, horse, reindeer, mountain hare and red fox  Bones of ious small mammals such as bats and shrews. It is anticipated that further bones of small mammals will be identied during post-excavation laboratory analysis. The archaeological excavation of the Ice Age animal remains has just been completed, but work continues offsite, where the bones are now being cleaned, conserved and studied in detail. A technically challenging site investigation, it has taken the dedicated team time to carefully explore and extract the findings, with sediment samples and an array of remains removed for research and preservation. Rob Bourn adds, “This investigation has been in exceptionally safe hands with the best professional archaeological team we could put together, uniting a group of specialist academics from across the UK with experts that have worked closely together over a long time. It has also involved a team working under the ground for weeks on end to recover the remains and take samples with the utmost care. We have worked with passion and professionalism to carry out thorough and diligent investigations.”  While all parties involved in these exciting discoveries recognise there will be public interest, people are asked not to visit the site. This area of Sherford is not suitable or safe to visit, and access is highly restricted in the interests of health and safety. Rob Bourn concludes, “A discovery like this would not have happened without the new town being created at Sherford the work to professionally recover, document and analyse the findings would not have been possible without the developers’ full cooperation and proactive approach to archaeology.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON AnimalsArchaeology" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: inside abandoned raf base played
story: Inside abandoned RAF base which played crucial role fighting Nazis during WWRAF Church Fenton in North Yorkshire was used by British pilots to defend some of Englands biggest cities from German bombers in the early stages of WWInside the abandoned RAF base once used to defend Britain against the Nazis Image: Jam Press Bearded RealityByRuby PensonLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments An abandoned RAF base has been left to rot after its crucial role in WW when it was used to defend Britain from the Nazis.Eerie photos show rotting walls, crumbling floors and vandalism throughout RAF Church Fenton in Tadcaster, North Yorkshire. Fearless pilots once used the base, which was built in , to help defend some of the biggest cities in England during the war.Some of the site continued to be used decades after the fighting but much of it has been left to decay for years, reports Yorkshire Live.During WWII, the airfield was home to ious aircraft from Hurricanes, Mosquitoes, Blenheims and Beaufighters to Typhoons and Mustangs. It also housed a fast but flimsy wooden aircraft called the de Havilland Mosquito which was only in service for a matter of months before being disused.  The base was tasked with defending some of the great industrial cities of northern England from German bombers at the beginning of the war. Some of Britainaposs very first night fighters flew out of the Yorkshire base with some paying the ultimate price to protect the nation. The site also hosted a signicant amount of squadrons including the firstRAF aposEagleapos Squadron of American volunteers, the first all-Canadian RAF Squadron, and the first all-Polish RAF Squadron.  Photographer Bearded Reality captured a series of pictures which show what is left of the base some eight decades later. The images offer an insight into what le would have been like for those who spent time there over the years. In a YouTube video, he shows some of the rooms that were covered in graffiti and taken over by nature including an old bar and kitchen area.  Debris hung from the ceilings while some of the flooring has collapsed. After the war ended, RAF Church Fenton was used as a frontline fighter station in the defence of northern England to the late s. Since then it has been falling apart and simply left to the elements. Initially, the station continued to be used after the war and its role changed to pilot training by .  But it was finally shut down for good in  by which time a number of its buildings had already fallen into disuse. The video shows Daniel and his companions running at dferent points after hearing other people in the building. At the end of the video, Daniel tells viewers: “That was RAF Fenton, AKA Leeds East Airport. Unfortunately, we couldn’t get into the tower because security rolled up right beside us. “The place is creepy but an amazing explore.”  After posting the video on YouTube, some viewers asked Daniel for more information about the site but he told them the buildings he visited were now gone. One wrote: “Cool abandoned place in Leeds I will be going there to paint.” Daniel replied: “The place is unfortunately gone but was a super cool place.” Another added: “Sad to see, flew here a couple of times as an air cadet.” Daniel responded: “Ohh thats amazing thank you for sharing and yes itaposs a shame itaposs gone.” Someone  said: “I’m so glad I subscribed to this channel.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON World War NazisPhotographyPlanesFrontline Fighters" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news inside-kate-middletons-special-bond-"Princes Charles, Camilla and Kate visit Trinity Buoy WharfByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Feb |comments Royal fans were given a rare insight into the close bond between the Duchess of Cambridge and the Duchess of Cornwall today. The pair made a joint visit, along with Prince Charles, to East London, where they met textiles students at a centre run by the Princeaposs Foundation.The two women were seen happily chatting and sharing a joke as they toured the centred and looked at ease in each otheraposs company.And itaposs no surprise they seemingly get along as both of had similar experiences of living in the normal world before having to navigate royal le after marrying their husbands.  Of course, both are also the wives of future Kings and appear to provide a supportive shoulder for their spouses. Here we look at their close bond... Dating advice As the older and more experienced of the two women, Camillaaposs bond with Kate seems to have been forged through offering advice. Camilla had joined the royal fold several years before Kate so knew what le was like within the Firm. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.Kate had a lot to learn, and she needed to do it quickly as she took on the role of royal girlfriend while dating Prince William. And it was Camilla who reached out to offer her future step-daughter-in-law a few words of advice, and theyaposre very telling.According to royal expert and biography Robert Lacey, Charlesaposs we had a little tip for Kate - but she struggled to follow it. In his book, Battle of Brothers, Lacey writes: Camilla had confided to Kate the secret of hanging on to a busy prince: fit your timetable - well, basically your whole le - around his. However, despite Camillaaposs advice, Lacey claims that this wasnapost really possible for Kate as Williamaposs diary was un-fit-roundable. Pre-wedding lunch  Several years later, Kateaposs entry into the Royal Family was confirmed when she became engaged to William. The couple immediately started planning their wedding at Westminster Abbey - and it seems Camilla was on hand to help.According to the Daily Mail, she was spotted having a long lunch with Kate and her sister Pippa as well as Camillaaposs daughter Laura just weeks before the big day.A fellow diner, sitting just two tables away, told the paperaposs Richard Kay me: All four women were talking away like mad and none of the waiters could get a word in edgeways to serve their lunch. Kate looked fantastic in a very short black skirt, black opaque tights, a short jacket and boots. I heard Camilla saying... apos I can give you one bit of advice...apos Kate was really enjoying the moment. Personalised gtKateaposs special bond with Camilla was also proved when the Duchess of Cornwall gted her Kate a personalised gold bracelet. The bracelet is thought to have been given as a wedding gt to celebrate Kate and William marrying.The chain-link bracelet features one single charm with engravings on either side, as is reported by Hello! Magazine. Each side of the little disc features a monogram - both Kateaposs and Camillaaposs. On one side is the letter aposCapos for Catherine, Kateaposs given name, with a coronet and on the other is a aposCapos for Camilla and a crown. Kate has only been seen wearing the bracelet in public a handful of times - including once at Wimbledon in  and again during the Santa Barbara Polo Match as part of her official royal tour to Calornia. It makes up part of her fabulous jewellery collection, which features a number of other sentimental items. Joint engagements  In recent times, there have been several royal engagements that both Camilla and Kate have attended together.Last year, the pair, along with their husbands attended the premiere of the James Bond movie No Time To Die together.While last June, they also took part in a fun engagement in Cornwall with the Queen, where Camilla helped Her Majesty cut a cake using a ceremonial sword. No upstaging Another day that saw the two royal women together was Remembrance Sunday during the service at the Cenotaph.At the last minute, the Queen had to pull out of attending due to a sprained back and when they took the position on the Foreign Office balcony, Kate stood centre stage with Camilla and Sophie Wessex at her side.Despite the positioning making Kate seem the more senior, body language expert Judi James said it appeared that Camilla was comfortable standing to the side.She told the Express : With the Queen sadly missing from the royal balcony this year there was a very intriguing and possibly signicant re-shuffle of the royal wives, with Kate emerging looking very much like the highest-ranking woman in the group, not just by taking the central position between Camilla and Sophie but by her non-verbal signals as she stood in that spot.“With Camilla next in line to the role of Queen [consort] it might have been expected for her to take that middle position between the two younger women. Camilla appears satisfied with her role.However, thataposs not to say Kate isnapost aware of Camillaaposs hierarchy in the family, according to royal expert Ingrid Seward.She told the Mirror: Prince Charles is not even King yet and the Royals are very careful about not upstaging each other. Kate will be keen not to upstage Camilla. “She is aware of hierarchy and that it is Camilla’s turn. news uk-news kate-middleton-wears-recycled-dress-"Princes Charles, Camilla and Kate visit Trinity Boat WharfByRussell MyersRoyal EditorJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments The Duchess of Cambridge joined Prince Charles and Camilla for a rare outing with her in-laws in London today.Kate was invited by her father-in-law on the visit to Trinity Buoy Wharf, a centre in East London run by the Princeaposs Foundation, where traditional textile skills are taught. For the outing, she wore a chic grey coat dress by Catherine Walker that she previously sported in  during an engagement with the Queen at Kingaposs College, London. She also carried a black Mulberry bag.Meanwhile, Camilla opted for a bottle green riding skirt and jacket with black boots and also carried a green Bvlgari handbag.During the visit the royal trio looked at ease as they posed by the Thames against the backdrop of the O Arena and the London skyline.  They then met students, who demonstrated their sewing machine skills and they even tried their hands at sewing a straight seam themselves. Kate and Camilla spoke to two home schooled sisters who joined a scheme with the Prince’s Foundation last year to learn fashion design, with a view to gaining work experience in the textiles industry.Soukayna and Safiya Ouhammou from Woodford, showed the Duchesses their designs for jumpers they are making as part of the course.  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. Soukayna, , said they started off by taking photographs on their phones of lily flowers on the river behind the centre, before sketching out their ideas that would lead to the design.She added: “We started by thinking about our inspiration from the things around us, so I took some pictures when we went for a walk by the river and the lily looked so beautul on the water.“It gave me the idea to make a contrast of colours on the jumper which could be stitched together, one on top of the other.”  Kate said: “It’s fascinating to see how the whole process works, it’s a great idea.” After being shown the sewing machines to stitch the materials together, Camilla said: “You’re obviously very good at this. I did it so long ago but I’m very bad at it now.” The royals also joined a le drawing class with the latest intake of students at the Foundation from September, although any potential blushes were spared as the model was fully clothed. Speaking to Imogen Lewis, , from Suffolk, Camilla joked: “I think I’d rather be doing the drawing with you!“It looks such fun. How long do you have to do it ” Kateaposs invitation to join the engagement is said to have been down to her shared interest and longstanding support of the arts and creative industries”. A royal aide said the visit was “especially signicant” as it was believed to be only the second time Kate has joined Charles and Camilla on an engagement together. In March , Kate joined the couple for an engagement at the Dulwich Picture Gallery in London while Prince William was away in the Falklands on an RAF posting.The last time she joined Charles and Camilla for a rare joint engagement was back in September when the trio, along with Prince William, attended the premiere of the James Bond movie No Time To Die. And these rare joint engagements could become more and more common in the future, according to royal sources.At the time, they told the Mirror that outing of Charles, Camilla, William and Kate could herald a new era of collaboration and solidarity between the future king and his eldest son and their wives. Meanwhile, it has been a busy few days for Kate, who announced yesterday she has been given two new royal patronages.She is now the patron of the English Rugby Football League and Rugby Football Union - two roles previously held by Prince Harry. And to mark her new jobs, she paid a visit to Twickenham yesterday, when she tackled a rugby training session. news uk-news mcvities-chocolate-digestive-compared-tesco-"I tried all the supermarkets own-brand chocolate digestives BySam HoneyLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsThe McVitieaposs Chocolate Digestive has been compared to own brand alternatives from Tesco, Aldi and MS to reveal a clear winner. Each biscuitaposs taste, dunking power, chocolate to biscuit ratio and crunch factor was compared against the McVitieaposs brand to seeit really does deserve the title the nationaposs favourite. The supermarket brand digestives were put to the test against a £ double pack of McVitieaposs alongside a humble cup of tea. One supermarket came awfully close to the true McVitieaposs taste while carrying a much cheaper price tag.While the other two retailers were no match for the iconic biscuit brand, according to the review by Kent Live.First on the tasting menu was Tescoaposs milk chocolate digestives, described as crumbly and crunchy and priced at p.  The biscuitaposs taste was said to be strikingly similar to the classic we all know and love with a great chocolatey flavour. But the texture set it apart as it was much crumblier than McVitieaposs and likened to a shortbread biscuit. Next up was the more luxurious Marks and Spencer supermarket brand which was described as rather good but with a few set backs.  Despite being ranked as the closest to McVitieaposs distinctive taste and texture, the reviewer felt just a little underwhelmed with its higher p price tag. The chocolate was described as tasting a little cheaper than expected and not on brand with the MS name in their taste test. Meanwhile Aldi supermarket offered sweet-toothed shoppers the cheapest chocolate digestive priced at just p.  But the budget-friendly supermarket option is also noticeably smaller than the other brands, according to the review. Its taste was described as the weakest by far with a noticeably cheaper chocolate that was compared to that of advent calendars. The biscuit was said to be harder in texture and its smaller size meant it was gone within two bites. Overall the review still favoured the McVitieaposs brand as well as the Tesco own brand alternative.  The reviewer said they were left feeling rather disappointed at the end of the taste test with regards to the chocolate digestives on offer at Aldi and MS. McVitieaposs remained in first place for the reviewer who gave credit to Tesco for coming pretty close and making a delicious biscuit. If I’m ever in Tesco and in the mood to save a few pennies, this will make a more than acceptable substitute to my usual, they added. title: mischievous prince harry only one
story: Mischievous Prince Harry was only one who could fool Queen with risky prankPrince William and Prince Harry would visit their grandmother, the Queen, at Windsor Castle while they were studying at Eton College just around the corner Image: Getty ImagesByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments Like many children, Prince Harry was very a very mischievous little boys and loved playing pranks on his family. According to royal insiders, the Duke of Sussex would play tricks on the Queen, his grandmother, and was the only one who could fool her.Harry and big brother Prince William would join their nan for tea on Sunday afternoons at her Windsor Castle home during their time studying at Eton College, which was just around the corner. And while William would be happy to just make conversation with his grandmother, Harry had more mischievous ideas up his sleeve. Former royal butler Paul Burrell said that heaposd seen Harry tricking the Queen with fake flies. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here.Speaking to OK! magazine, Paul said: I know the Queen very well and I know she’s very fond of Harry.As William would sit and have tea with her after school, Harry would come and put plastic flies in the sugar bowl! It was hilarious. Harry was the only one who could trick his granny. And it seems Harry got his mischievous charisma from his mum Diana, who was known for her sense of humour. Not only did Diana approve of her sonaposs cheeky side, she actively encouraged his funny pranks. She loved Christmas and would put a lot of effort into finding her kids the perfect gists, always hoping to make them laugh. One year, Paul recalled Diana gting Harry a piece of fake dog poo. Speaking to the Mirror, he said: Sheaposd spend hours looking for jokey things for their stockings. One year, Harry got fake dog poo. Harry thought it was hilarious and had a very cheeky plan for it - he was planning to hide it somewhere for his nan to find. The Queen wasnapost Harryaposs only victim though, as heaposs been known to wreak havoc at the Althorp estate. When Prince Charles and Diana brought William and Harry to Althorp, Harry was a little mischief, recalled the estate chef. He was stuffing slippers down the loo! he said.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. news uk-news moment-sadistic-girl--hugged-"Dionne Timms-Williams questioned after death of Dr Gary Jenkins in ByAntony Thrower:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsAn evil and sadistic girl and her two male pals were seen hugging together after brutally punching a gay doctor to death. Dr Gary Jenkins was violently assaulted in Bute Park, in Cardf, in July , causing him multiple severe brain injuries. He died  days later. Jason Edwards, , Lee Strickland, , and Dionne Timms-Williams, , admitted taking part in the assault on Dr Jenkins and pleaded guilty to manslaughter and robbery. They also pleaded guilty to assaulting another man who tried to protect the victim. All three were convicted of murder after an eight-day trial at Merthyr Crown Court in South Wales. The prosecution said the attack had been motivated by greed, homophobia and straight-up violence.  An audio recording was played to the court from a CCTV camera located inside a cafe near where the trio brutally attacked Dr Jenkins. Before the clip was played, members of the jury and others in the courtroom were warned about its disturbing content, which gave an account of how Dr Jenkins was cruelly beaten, robbed, tortured and left for dead. Beginning just before am, a man identied as Dr Jenkins can be heard repeatedly yelling Leave me alone and Get off me. A female voice - Timms-Williams - shouts Money and Now, before homophobic slurs are used by one of the male defendants, believed to be Edwards, who has a Liverpool accent. Dr Jenkins makes repeated pleas for his le, asking Why  and saying Please, stop it.  His moans of pain later become quieter before he is unable to speak any more. Timms-Williams can be heard saying Get down, Do it all over again, Do it and Hit him again. Another male voice at one point says: Stamp on his head. Stamp on his head too. Another says Keep going and Oh, let me stamp on him again. The attack lasts for  minutes, after which Timms-Williams can be heard saying: Yeah, I needed that. Witness Louis Williams can be heard throughout, attempting to intervene, before the three defendants turn and assault him. He told police that he attempted to lie on top of Dr Jenkins to shield him from the repeated kicks and punches.  Mr Williams said the three defendants laughed and shouted as they carried out the violence, and he thought Timms-Williams was evil and sadistic. He said: I couldnapost understand why they were hurting him so much.” Following the attack, Strickland could be seen on CCTV footage heading back to the Esso garage where he bought a bottle of whiskey using Dr Jenkinsapos Santander debit card. Timms-Williams and Edwards emerged from the North Road entrance and hugged and kissed each other for a number of minutes before they separated. In a prepared statement the teenager gave to police, she said she only joined in with the attack because she had been scared of the two men. Her defence team also claimed she was not homophobic and that she had been in a same-sex relationship. Following the verdict, Mr Enoch told the jury that a piece of evidence which had not been put before them was a statement from Stricklandaposs ex-girlfriend saying he had targeted gay men in the park regularly.  Judge Williams sent both Edwards and Strickland out of the dock for laughing and joking, behaviour which he said they had been displaying throughout the trial, before sending Timms-Williams down. He said the three will be sentenced on March  at Cardf or Newport crown court. The family of Dr Gary Jenkins,said in a prepared statement: “Gary was such a kind soul who would never hurt anyone. He was an incredibly generous and creative man who had only good intentions. Gary’s private le, being put on display through a Crown Court trial has only intensied the impact of this event on our family, friends and colleagues. It has been horrible to have to listen to the details of what happened. We cannot bring Gary back. There are no winners in this case, only losers but as a family we are relieved that justice is done.” Senior Investigating Officer, Detective Inspector Stuart Wales added: “Dr Gary Jenkins was a much-loved father, husband, brother and friend. “The attack upon Dr Jenkins by the three defendants was cowardly and senseless in the extreme. “The degree and duration of unnecessary violence inflicted upon him, together with homophobic abuse - all captured on audio, was both sickening and staggering “He did nothing whatsoever to warrant this.”Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Gary JenkinsCCTVMurder trialCrime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum livid frightened girl 10
story: Mum livid as frightened girl, , abandoned in dark by bus driver due to faulty machineDaiva Paskeviciene, from Edinburgh, said that her daughter was twice denied on board buses due to a problem with her pass and is now scared to use public transportA mum was left fuming after her daughter was twice denied on buses Image: edinburghliveByIona YoungTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsA furious mum has told how her frightened -year-old daughter was left in the dark and cold after a bus driver wouldnapost allow her on board due to a faulty ticket machine. Daiva Paskeviciene, from Edinburgh,said that her daughter, a pupil at Tollcross Primary School, was not allowed on the bus because her pass did not work, and claimed it was a fault with the machine.The first alleged incident happened on January  when the schools had just gone back after Christmas break, reported EdinburghLive.Ms Paskeviciene said she received a call from her terried daughter after she was left alone waiting in the cold for  minutes for another bus home. The -year-old is claimed to have presented her junior ridacard, that had been topped up that morning, to the machine on the bus. The driver told her it wasnapost working so she could not get on and would have to leave the bus. Ms Paskeviciene told EdinburghLive: My daughter is in P at Tollcross and is -years-old, it happened after Christmas when schools went back. Usually she gets the bus, on that day at around .pm. She went to the bus with her bus card that I topped up that morning. The machine wasnapost working so the driver told her she couldnapost get on the bus. He then got angry and was shouting at her. She got really scared. The bus stop was at Lothian Road, she had to wait  minutes for the next one it got dark and very cold. She called me and eventually a stranger had to give her money to be able to get home. Next time I made sure she had spare change just in case.  I couldnapost believe a driver would act like that to a little girl then it happened again. She got a new bus card the free Young Scot one, it worked in the morning on the bus but again when she was trying to get on the  after school, she tapped her card and it didnapost work. The driver said, aposyour card doesnapost work, you arenapost coming onapos my daughter called me crying, and is now afraid to catch the bus to school. A spokesman for Lothian Buses said: Lothian is committed to delivering safe, reliable public transport for all of our customers. We would always ask that our customers contact our customer services teamthey have concerns regarding their travel experience and would encourage this customer to contact us directly with more information to allow us to investigate the matter. title: mum rations herself two cups
story: Exclusive: Mum rations herself to two cups of tea a day due to rocketing energy pricesRebecca turns the thermostat down to C when her daughter is at school and closes the blinds to keep as much warmth in as possible as she simply cant afford to heat her house properlyRebecca and her daughter have been hit hard by rising energy prices Image: MATTHEW USHERByMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsA single mum rations her tea consumption to two cups a day due to the sharply rising cost of energy. Rebecca and her nine-year-old daughter often snuggle up in bed together early in the evening to try and escape the bitter cold of their home. Since the -year-oldaposs hospitality work dried up during lockdown, making ends meet on Universal Credit has been a real struggle. Despite being desperate to work full-time again, the benefits taper and child care costs that need to be paid upfront means sheaposs better off doing just a couple of days a week. Rebecca, who is among the .million people who recently had their benefits cut by £ a month, is now desperately trying to meet her rising food and energy bills. Power costs for homes are set to go up by almost £ from this April, regulator Ofgem confirmed today. The move will affect some  million households and follows a % rise in October.  To make sure her daughter doesnapost go without, the Australian national cuts her portions as much as possible. She also avoids eating hot food to keep energy costs low, meaning she survives mostly on fruit and bread, and rations her tea consumption to two cups a day. It used to be that Iaposd have the same quantities as my daughter, but now I eat less, Rebecca explained. I have to cut other things down to pay for food. When my daughter is at school I turn my thermostat down to C. Do you struggle to heat your home  Are you worried about the price rises in April  Comment below or email webnews@mirror I keep the curtains closed rather than letting the sunshine in. I have a giant poncho on and blanket over my legs. I donapost know what I will do in April. Rebecca is one of millions of Brits who faced a big energy bill hike of % in October, and are now looking at another % rise when the price cap is lted in April. The number of people living in fuel poverty - which means spending % or more of their income on energy bills - is expected to triple to % or  million homes in two months time. Having to cut back on heating and scrimp where to pay the bills can be tough. Being cold and hungry for most of the day leaves Rebecca with overwhelming anxiety and causes her to zone out while sheaposs playing with her daughter. The mum is convincedshe had a lump sum of money to pay for childcare so she could work, and for insulation to keep her energy bills down, sheaposd be able to lt herself out of her current miserable situation. We need a system that supports people so that their wellbeing and their tummies are okay, so they can be al humans in society, she said. My experience of poverty in the UK is that it is a terrible trap. I am here in poverty not from my own choosing. I canapost escape. I am not lazy. I really do work hard. I have been trying to come up with solutions, but there are just none. The governmentaposs job is to even society out, but that is not how it works now. People have forgotten that le shouldnapost be a struggle.  Another pair who are living in a frosty house without free-flowing hot water are Meg and William Miller, who describe their situation as like living in the Victoria era. They are two of an estimated six million Brits whose water and homes are heating by oil, rather than electricity or gas. Rather than paying a month energy bill, oil users have to pay up front to fill up a large tank. For Meg, , and William,  - who has Parkinsonaposs disease - filling a  litre tank requires the kind of cash they simply donapost have, especially now that oil prices have tripled since May  to p a litre. As a result the couple are forced to keep their lights off during the evenings and share bath water to keep costs down. When the temperatures in their home plummet, William and Meg sleep in the living room next to their wood burner. The sitting room is warm, but my bedroom is colder than outside the house, Meg, a recently retired transport and distribution manager, told The Mirror. It is not nice. The last tank of oil I bought was two years ago, but we canapost afford to use it for anything but for warm water to do the dishes. We were brought up in the cold, but you would expect in  to have running hot water. I hate not having that. We have worked all our lives and paid our dues. the least we can expect is a warm house with running water. It feels like it is back to the Victorian times. For other people, furniture poverty has combined with fuel poverty to create a particularly dficult situation this winter. Heather Humphries, from Poole, is a full time carer for her ex-partner and looks after her  and -year-old sons.While money has always been tight, until recently the thrty mum was managing to get by.Pre-paid food and electricity cards that she tops up in bulk at the beginning of each month are running out quicker and quicker, forcing Heather to skip meals so her sons can eat.The family wrap themselves up in cardigans and dressing gowns throughout the day so they can keep the thermostat as low as possible, and the boys are only allowed to switch their console on for a short period each day.As energy and food prices creep up, Heather has found it increasingly dficult to put aside any cash for items such as furniture and white goods.Over the past year a bed she bought second hand has fallen apart, leaving her to prop it up on a microwave to keep off the cold floor.The frame of one of her sonaposs bed has also started to crack. When it eventually breaks fully, Heather has no idea how sheaposll replace it.The microwave clinks and clunks beneath the bed, she said.If I move too far over the bed topples, so I end up being on the sofa. It is freezing.  Heather is particularly worried about how sheaposll keep putting food on the table and money in the metre come April.She said: I donapost know what I will do in April when the energy prices go up.It feels like theyaposve gone up a lot already I was putting in around £ a month last year, now itaposs £ to £ to keep warm.I really donapost know what Iaposm going to do. Iaposm hoping for warm weather.The -year-old is one of an estimated .million people in the UK unable to afford basic furniture or home appliances.End Furniture Poverty is one of several British charities helping people like Heather replace essential household items.Theyaposve had their work cut-out since , when the government abolished crisis loans and community care grants and replaced them with local welfare assistance schemes.While the new system aims to help people in times of crisis, they receive % less funding than the schemes it replaced. Claire Donovan, Campaigns Manager for End Furniture Poverty, said: “For millions of people living in Furniture Poverty, local welfare assistance is a vital leline, helping them to access essential furniture items like cookers, beds and fridges.“A decade of austerity, followed by the immense challenges during the pandemic, mean that millions more are now struggling, so we urge the Government to adequately fund and ring fence LWAS budgets, and provide clear guidance for local authorities to end this postcode lottery of support.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Energy billsFuel povertyOil prices" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: national lottery voucher offer deal
story: Get a £ voucher* for the UKs best attractions using a National Lottery ticketYou can use a Lotto ticket to claim a £ voucher* to redeem when booking any one of hundreds of attractionsAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Jan Whether you’re eight or , exploring new places brings out the adventurer inside us all. And in the UK we’re spoiled for choice, with hundreds of incredible attractions to fire up the imagination. Thrill seekers of all ages will find adrenaline-filled rides at Zip World or Legoland. Those who prefer a more relaxing experience can enjoy autumn’s spectacular show of colours at venues like Kew Gardens, Cardf Castle or RHS Garden Bridgewater – a major horticultural project near Salford. History fans will adore a trip to the gothic ruins at Whitby Abbey, Warwick or Stirling Castle, while animal lovers can meet Ruby the red panda, born in July at Edinburgh Zoo, or three adorable tiger cubs at Highland Wildle Park. Click here toabout National Lottery Days Out and redeem your £ voucher*. And you can use a Lotto ticket purchased on or after October ,  to claim a £ voucher* to redeem when booking any one of hundreds of attractions. Not only will you enjoy a discounted day trip, you can feel proud that you’ve helped fund many of the tourist and heritage sites that make the UK unique. By playing The National Lottery, you raise £million for good causes every week.  National Lottery players have supported  of the top  most visited tourist attractions in the UK**, from castles to wildle parks, botanical gardens to museums and plenty of other fun stuff. Every adventure starts with a finger on a map. So where will yours land Highland Wildle Park: Meet animals from all over the world  Get up close to some endangered animals from the world’s mountains and tundra in the stunning setting of the Cairngorms National Park. From the comfort of your car you’ll encounter bison, elk and red deer – then visit the tigers and polar bears on foot using the park’s trails. Many nativeanimals are here too, including the capercaillie, European grey wolf, wolverine, lynx, Scottish wildcat and beavers.Cardf Castle: Enjoy a great day in history It has a history that stretches back to Roman times, a keep dating from the Norman Conquest, a spectacular moat and great views over the city that sits just beside it. Cardf Castle makes for one brilliant family day out. You’ll learn that it was once home to the world’s richest man, and was used as a giant air raid shelter during the Nazi bombardment of the city. Kids will love standing beside the huge replica trebuchet – a six-ton medieval weapon built for a movie that was filmed at the castle. After you’ve toured the building, stroll around its beautul grounds, or explore the city itself.Stonehenge: Explore this wonderful World Heritage Site Get close to this mysterious monument that dates back nearly , years. This awe-inspiring embodiment of human ingenuity offers a direct connection to our ancient past, and is a bucket-list destination for visitors around the world. title: our community heroes deserve new
story: Our community heroes deserve a new Thank Holiday to celebrate their hard workBear Grylls OBE, Chief Scout, says that in every community, there are unsung heroes quietly making them great places to live - and they deserve to be celebratedCelebrations during the Queens Diamond Jubilee in  Image: Ealing Gazette  LeaderopinionByBear Grylls OBE:,  Feb |commentsHundreds of organisations are calling for the Government to create a new annual “thank” holiday next year.They would like the extra day off to thank the Queen for her  years of incredible service and to celebrate the quiet hard work of local volunteers. Here, Bear Grylls OBE, Chief Scout, explains why it should happen...In every community, there are unsung heroes quietly making them great places to live. These are the helpers, the organisers, the volunteers and change makers who think of others before themselves. It’s their kindness that makes communities strong. But they’re not the sort of people to show off. They just keep going, day in day out. I admire that. But they deserve our thanks too.  That’s why, in this jubilee year, hundreds of organisations from the Scouts and Girlguiding to the Royal Voluntary Service and Confederation of British Industry are calling on the Government to create a new Bank Holiday from . This is a day for everyone for people to get together with friends and neighbours, to say thank you and celebrate the generosity that lies at the heart of communities. People can spend it how they like – helping others or taking a well-earned rest, together. The campaign comes ahead of the th anniversary of the Queen’s accession to the throne on February , . That’s  years of incredible service.  So the Thank Holiday would recognise her extraordinary dedication, and say thank you to the millions of others who do so much, with much less recognition. In Scouts alone, we have over , volunteers helping young people gain skills for le. This Thank Holiday can only happenwe all get behind it.  It’s a day to get to know each other better, to be thankful, celebrate our dferences and appreciate what we’ve got in common. Above all, it’s a chance to get together and reconnect. Now’s the time for us to champion those who step up in our communities. Let’s ask for a special day to honour them.You can add your backing hereRead MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Confederation of British IndustryDaily MirrorHolidays" data-immediate"data-immediate"Fancy an escape to the Chill newsletter for weekly inspiration and advice on UK holidays Sign Up!Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
